titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: I. V. Saturday.

I called this morning at the General Post-Office, but was told the Postmaster General was and had been for some time sick.— I saw, Selah R. Hobbie, one of his deputies, and spoke to him of the Bill reported by the Committee of Commerce, appropriating 10,000 dollars to build a Custom-house at Plymouth— I told him that the Memorial from Plymouth had asked an Appropriation of 12000 dollars for a building to accommodate both the Custom house, and Post-Office— That the Secretary of the Treasury had informed me that the expence of that part of the building intended for the Post-Office must be defrayed by that department; as the Treasury Department could only recommend the expenditure for the Post-Office— Mr Hobbie took minutes of what I said and promised to answer me in writing— He said however that the same union of Custom-house and Post-Office had been undertaken at New-York, and in that case there had only been a recommendatory Letter from the Post-master General to the Secretary of the Treasury, who had thereupon undertaken to defray the whole expense of both parts of the building— While I was at the Post-Office, the Masonic procession consisting of the members of the Grand Lodge of the District, and the New Jerusalem Lodge marched by, escorted by the Band of Music of the Marine Corps.— There were upwards of 100 men—arrayed in all their paraphernalia to attend the funeral of Henry Ashton, the Marshal of the District who died the day before yesterday— I paid a visit to F. C. Gray, at Gadsby’s and found J. Reed with him— I then sat for my Portrait, near two hours to Mr Peale Mr George Bender, late a Major in the army, brought me a Memorial to Congress which he had requested me, and I had promised to present for him to the House next Monday. It is for double-rations and 2 1/2 per Cent allowance on expenditures from 7 April 1829 to 10 December 1832, being in charge of the Delaware Breakwater— He wishes that the Memorial, may be referred to the Committee of Claims— We had a very miscellaneous company to dine with us—among whom were judge Burnet of Ohio, and Judge Pope of Illinois.
2. V:30. Sunday.

I took my Son John’s child Mary Louisa, with me to the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr E. Smith from Psalm 112.10.—“The desire of the wicked shall perish.” By the wicked, Mr Smith desired some of his hearers, to understand themselves to be indicated, and there were parts of his discourse, which I thought scarcely reverend. He represented the wicked as struggling successfully against God—as defeating the deliberate purposes and wishes of God—as prostrating God— I could hardly sit and hear him with Patience— In the afternoon, at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening prayer for the third Sunday in Lent, and preached a short discourse from Colossians 1.19. “For it pleased the father that in him should all fulness dwell.” There was some slight variation in this Sermon from the usual tenor of Mr Hawley’s— The weather has been for several days so warm that some of the trees are putting forth
their leaves; but a brisk Northwester this day has brought winter back again. The latter part of this Evening I employed in reading, but of occupation suitable for the day, I am still deprived by the encroachments of the week upon the Sabbath, and the Variety of subjects which successively grasp my attention is so distracting that I am unable to fix it upon any one thing effectively.
3. VII. Monday.

Having been up last Evening till near Midnight, the Sun this morning rose before me, an incident which I think had not before happened this Winter— I lost of course the precious time for writing. At the House the day was consumed in receiving Memorials, and resolutions of popular Meetings for and against the removal of the deposits and the recharter of the Bank of the United States— Last Monday the call for Petitions commencing with the State of Maine, had proceeded only as far as Pennsylvania, which State was this day first called by the Speaker— William Heister presented Resolutions from the County of Lancaster, with a short preliminary Address— At his request they were read, and were against the removal of the Deposits, and in favour of the Bank— He then presented twenty other Memorials of the same purport, which without reading were at his motion referred to the Committee of Ways and Means— John Galbraith and Robert Ramsay presented Memorials from their respective Districts. H. Binney presented one from Northampton, which had been sent to him, because the opinions of the Representative from that District, David B. Wagener did not accord with those of the Memorial— Harmar Denny presented a memorial from a Bank at Pittsburgh, and one from a numerous meeting in the County of Alleghany— The Speaker presented Resolutions from a Meeting in Chester County, which at Potts’s motion were read, and from a Meeting of the City and County of Philadelphia, which at the motion of Sutherland were read. Henry King presented Memorials and Resolutions on both sides of the questions—read. Sutherland presented a Memorial signed by four thousand working men of the third Congressional District (Watmough’s) against the Bank and the restoration of the Deposits— Watmough makes enquiry who the signers were; and Sutherland answers that he will find them no men of straw—and that the Memorial was transmitted to him by a gallant old revolutionary Soldier— Watmough hints that Sutherland himself got up the memorial That it was clandestinely circulated for signatures, and that it was signed by many not belonging to the District.— He asks the printing of the Memorial with the names of the signers—ordered—Watmough presents two Memorials with Resolutions, from the same District in favour of the Bank— And several others were presented, by other members from Pennsylvania— J. J. Milligan presented a Memorial and Resolutions in favour of the Bank, from the County of Newcastle, Delaware, which he introduced by a short Speech— There were two or three Memorials from Maryland, and John J. Gordon, presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Virginia, against the removal of the deposits, and against the Constitutionality of the Bank of the United States— Gordon made a moderate Speech in support of the Resolutions— John M. Patton asked that the Letter from Governor Floyd enclosing the Resolutions, should be read, and then commenced a Speech of three hours against Floyd and against the Resolutions.— Floyd’s term as Governor
expires this day— Patton spared neither him nor the Legislature, and prophesied that the People of Virginia would not spare them— Archer said to me it was the most disgraceful Speech he ever heard— But it was a strong and able Speech— Patton censured on all sides—the Proclamation, the State of South Carolina; the removal of the deposits—the Bank—but finally sustained every act of the President in this contest— When he closed Gholson obtained the floor, declared he approved entirely the Resolutions of the Legislature and moved the house should adjourn— Carried— It was six O’Clock— I. M’Kim presented a Memorial from Baltimore against the Bank
4. VI.25. Tuesday.

At the House, Polk, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, presented a Report on the Reasons of the Secretary of the Treasury for removing the Deposits, and on the Memorials of the President and Directors of the U.S. Bank complaining of a violation of the Charter contract by their removal, and demanding reparation, the memorial of the Government Directors accusing the other Directors, and sundry other Memorials— The report concludes with four Resolutions 1. That the Bank of the United States ought not to be rechartered 2. That the public deposits ought not to be restored— 3. That the deposits should be continued in the State Banks under regulations to be prescribed by Law. 4. That a travelling Committee of investigation be appointed to examine and report upon the affairs and Corruptions of the Bank of the United States as soon as practicable— Clay of Alabama moved for the reading of the report—objection was made, but the Speaker decided that a paper being offered, before it is in possession of the House, it must be read at the call of any one member; but that after it has been received by the House the question of reading depends upon the pleasure of the House— Part of the report was accordingly read, when Clay consented that the reading of the remainder should be suspended it being understood that he should have leave to move the printing of an extra number of copies of the Report— He moved for 10000— H Binney presented a counter-report from the minority of the Committee (Binney, Gorham and Wilde) This was received, and it was agreed that an equal number of both Reports should be printed. Hawes moved 50000 copies—rejected— J. Reed 20000 copies, rejected. Hall of Maine 15000 copies—carried. Ewing of Indiana, remonstrating against the printing of the Reports at-all— Polk moved to postpone the consideration of the Report till to-morrow week, which was carried, against a motion of M’Duffie to refer it to the Committee of the whole on the Union— Wilde asked the unanimous consent of the House that an Amendment which he intended to propose to the Resolutions reported by the Committee should be printed— Objection made, he moved a suspension of the rule—a majority but not two thirds for it— The house then passed to the orders of the day. There were numerous Bills reported by the standing Committees, and Archer Chairman of the Committee of foreign Relations asked that the Committee should be discharged from the further consideration of the President’s Message concerning the present of the Lion from the Emperor of Morocco—and other presents— The Bill for the Settlement of certain revolutionary claims was taken up Vanderpoel
of New-York, made a speech of about an hour against it; and Muhlenberg of Pennsylvania, a speech not quite so long in its favour— Brown of New-York about 3. O’Clock took the floor and moved an adjournment which was carried— Coll. R. M. Johnson called me out, and intreated me to support the appropriation for his Indian School, which he expected would be attacked— Cambreleng gave me to read his report on the Petitions for the Warehousing system— Edward Everett gave me to read a Letter from Caleb Cushing, a Royal Arch Mason and member of the Massachusetts Legislature— It says that some of the members of the Legislature wish that the Legislative Resolutions on the Currency should be presented to the House of Representatives here by Governor Lincoln, and asks Everett to give explanations to me to make it acceptable to me— He says Governor Davis has promised to write to Grennell (a mason) about it; but that it must not be thought Governor Lincoln desired it, and that it was first proposed by a person who had a great respect for me— I asked Everett if he had any explanation to give me, to make it acceptable to me— He said none; and that he had even hesitated whether he should shew me the Letter— I said the reason given by Mr Cushing did not appear to me to be sufficient— If there were some members who wished they might be presented by Governor Lincoln— I supposed there were others who would prefer that they should be presented by me, and if the former were a majority they might pass a Resolution that they should be presented by him— Everett said they certainly would not do that— I said I had at the request of the whole delegation presented the Resolutions of the Legislature at the last Session of Congress, and I presumed it would be generally expected that I should present these; rather than an entirely new Member— But I was perfectly willing the Delegation should determine by whom they should be presented— He said he thought that would be a proper course, and that he himself thought they ought to be presented by me— I wrote a little this Evening.
5. VI. Wednesday.

Levi Lincoln took his seat as a member from the fifth District of Massachusetts and was sworn by the Speaker— Joseph Vance of Ohio moved to suspend the 17th. rule; to continue the call of the States for Petitions and Memorials; and called for the yeas and nays. There was some discussion, whether it would not open the debate upon the Resolutions from the Legislature of Virginia—but Gholson consented to postpone till next Monday his reply to Patton, and the rule was suspended by a vote of 155 to 37.— Virginia was called. Wilson presented a Memorial from Wheeling, and Loyall one from Norfolk in favour of the Bank— Connor of North-Carolina one from Fayetteville, specially instructing him to vote in favour of the Bank— He certified the great respectability of the Memorialists and moved that the Memorial should be laid on the table and printed— W. B. Shepard presented a memorial in favour of the Bank, and Deberry another. South-Carolina, blank— Georgia Wilde presented a Memorial from Augusta, with some remarks to which Wayne declared his purpose in due time to reply— Hardin presented two or three Memorials from Kentucky, and obtained the unanimous consent of the house to offer a Resolution— Then asked consent to offer another— Objection made, and he asked the suspension of the rule— The Speaker said the Rule had already been suspended for another purpose, and Hardin gave it up— R. M. Johnson presented a Memorial in favour of the Bank, requesting him to vote accordingly— He made a Patelin speech in honour of the
memorialists, but without saying how he should vote—all non-committal. Chittenden Lyon presented two Memorials of the same purport, but without comment— Robert Mitchell of Ohio presented two Memorials, one favourable to the Bank, and one against it. John Carr of Indiana presented Resolutions of a Meeting against the removal of the deposits— I presented the Petition of George Bender, late a Major in the army of the United States, praying compensation for services, in superintending the Delaware Breakwater—referred to the Committee of Claims.— I gave the Chairman Elisha Whittlesey, the certificate of General Jesup, with the endorsement of the Secretary of War, Lewis Cass— John Reed presented a Memorial from New-Bedford against the removal of the deposits, and for the recharter of the Bank and made a Speech, in spite of the Speaker. At Mr Hard’s request, I presented a petition from the Inhabitants of Niagara County, New-York, for a survey, to make a ship canal, round the falls of Niagara, and an Appropriation—referred to the Committee of roads and canals. Heman Allen presented a Memorial from Burlington, Vermont, for the restoration of the Deposits and the recharter of the Bank.— Ellsworth of Connecticut, Heman Allen of Vermont, and Samuel Beardsley of New-York, Lytle, Leavitt and Sloane of Ohio presented sundry Petitions for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— They were all referred to the Committee on the District— There was doubtless concert in the production of all these Memorials in a cluster; but they were not supported by the members who presented them— Mr Ellsworth only said he wished to be understood as concurring in all the Sentiments expressed by the Petitioners— Beardsley presented a Memorial of the Inhabitants of Jamestown, Chatauqua County—against the United States Bank—signed by 539 persons—laid on the table and ordered to be printed; as were multitudes of other memorials, and petitions— Adjourned at 4 O’Clock— Mr De Graeff called me out to Mr Joseph W. Brown, of Tecumseh in the Territory of Michigan, a brother of the late General Jacob Brown, who wished me to offer a Resolution, to erect a monument over the remains of General Brown, which I promised to do, if there should be a prospect of success— I spoke of it to Elisha Whittlesey of Ohio—who promised to support it— Thomas F. Foster of Georgia, laid before the House three Resolutions of the Legislature of that State, against any Law, for distributing the proceeds of the public Lands among the several States—laid on the table.
6. V. Thursday.—

The occupations of the day are so much confined to my attendance upon the House of Representatives that I have seldom time to note any thing that happens to me out of it.— I asked the consent of the House to offer a Resolution, calling on the Secretary of the Treasury for information respecting the unavailable funds— Objection was made— I asked a suspension of the rule. On the question’s being taken, it appeared there was not a Quorum— When the members came in the vote was taken again and carried. My Resolution was received and laid over, one day— Several other Resolutions were admitted in the same way— M’Kay of N. Carolina asked leave to offer a Resolution without success— Then Mardis’s Resolution, relating to the selection of deposit Banks was taken up— I rose to move that it be laid on the table; but Clowney had not finished his Speech, and retained the floor— He finished, and A. S. Clayton of Georgia followed him in reply to Mardis— He had not finished when the hour expired. Polk moved to take up one of the appropriation Bills, but withdrew the motion— The Bill for the settlement of certain revolutionary claims was the unfinished business, and Brown of New-York spoke half an hour in support of the Bill— Wise of Virginia, followed, and began by saying he must excuse himself from supporting the Bill, being himself one of the claimants for the commutation—which it was its object to provide—his speech nevertheless, not ineloquent was warm in favour of the Bill; not considering it as in the nature of a pensionary grant; for as
a patriotic Virginian, he must of course be opposed to any and every Pension system, but this he considered as a claim of sheer right and Justice— Gilmer of Georgia opposed the Bill, and moved its recommitment without Instructions— Thomas Marshall, who as a member of the Committee of Revolutionary claims had reported the Bill, now replied to Gilmer and all the other objectors, but did not finish his Speech— The House adjourned at 1/2 past 3.
7. V. Friday.

Before the Meeting of the House, I called upon Roger B. Taney, Secretary of the Treasury, and read to him, the Letter from the Postmaster General, concerning the Post-Office at Plymouth. Mr Barry in this Letter declares his approbation of the plan, of connecting a provision for the Post-Office, in connection with that for building a Custom-house— Says the same arrangement has been adopted for the city of New-York, and that he is fully disposed to aid my wishes in this matter. In conversation with Mr Taney, I referred him to the case of New-York, and to what S. R. Hobbie had said to me— He thought it would be best to obtain a special appropriation for the cost of the Post-Office— I had conversation with him also upon the Memorials, and upon Cambreleng’s report in favour of a warehousing and credit system, which seems to be no favourite of Mr Taney’s— At the house, Thompson of Ohio, by unanimous consent introduced a Resolution, proposing a grant of Public Lands to the State of Ohio, to aid the State in the Construction of a Canal, to connect the Ohio Canal, with the Pennsylvania Canal, by the Sandy and Beaver route— Referred to the Committee of Roads and Canals, after striking out at the motion of Stewart of Pennsylvania, that the grant should be to the State of Ohio— It occasioned a debate between Thompson and Whittlesey of Ohio, which consumed the first hour— The Orders of the day came— Polk moved a suspension of the rules confining the house to private business, to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union—vote 67 to 40. no Quorum— Vote taken again 74 to 49.—not two thirds— The house then went into Committee of the whole on sundry private Bills— Connor in the Chair— Bill for the relief of Susan Decatur and others laid aside by consent— A multitude of Bills reported to the House without amendment, and two or three with amendments— Bill for grant of compensation to David Kilbourn an American Canadian Spy—discussed by Thompson of Ohio—Grennell and Wardwell—postponed for further consideration till next Friday, together with a bill for the relief of Gaetano Carusi— Thomas of Louisiana gets the rule suspended, and moves the House to adjourn over till Monday— Has a Skirmish of debate with Elisha Whittlesey of Ohio— Question made whether the motion to adjourn over is debateable— The Speaker says the practice is otherwise— That he never heard the question made—but he allowed Whittlessey and Thomas to debate it.— The House refused the yeas and nays, and adjourned over to Monday.— I received the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts on the currency and the deposits— Ben. Gorham and John Reed came to me and said it was the Sentiment of the whole Delegation that I should present the Resolutions to the House.

8. IV. Saturday.— I gave a sitting of about an hour to Mr Rembrandt Peale, who is painting my Portrait. It was abridged by the coming in of Mr George W. Lay, the member of the House, from Batavia, New-York, with Mrs Lay whose Portrait Mr Peale is also occupied in painting— I gave way of course, and went to the Library at the Capitol, where I consulted Pope’s Iliad, for the Lines in which Hector expresses the Sentiment, that it is the duty of Friendship to share in the Resentments as well as in the Love of the friend,

lg.l: “A generous friendship, no cold medium knows—
Burns with one Love, with one resentment glows.
One, should our interests, one our Passions be—
My friend, must hate the man that injures me.”

div.p: I consulted also Leland’s Demosthenes, for the Sentiment that abuses of Government, are usually discovered, by impulses of private enmity; which is as true in these days as it was at Athens in her oratorical days— I walked home, and on my way home, met Mr Philip Hone of New-York and afterwards Mr Huntington, the member of the House from Connecticut, with Mr Elihu Chauncey of Philadelphia— Mr Hone and Mr Chauncey are here as members of deputations from Memorialists of their respective Cities, upon the Bank and deposit controversies I dined with Mr John C. Calhoun, at Dowson’s— Mr Preston the other Senator from South-Carolina, and his wife, were there—the Lady in delicate health.— Mangum of North Carolina,—Southard Sprague of Maine, and John H. Fulton, a member of the House from Virginia— After dinner came in Benjamin Watkins Leigh, Senator from Virginia Samuel M’Dowell Moore of Virginia, Dixon H Lewis of Alabama, and Warren R Davis of South-Carolina, members of the House the company sat late at table, and the conversation was chiefly upon politics.— The company are all at this time adversaries of the present Administration—most of them were adversaries to the last— General Taylor of Ohio, a lodger at Dowson’s was also of the party.—
9. VI. Sunday.

Heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Smith from Galations 5.25. “If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit”— The distinction between the Spirit and the flesh is more strongly marked in the chapter from which this text is taken, than perhaps in any other part of the Scriptures— All vices and crimes are said to be the works of the flesh, and all the virtues are denominated the fruit of the Spirit— In the afternoon I attended at St. John’s Church where Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the fourth Sunday in lent, and a Sermon from Luke 19.42. “Saying, if thou hadst known, even thou, in this thy day, the things which belong unto thy Peace! but now, they are hid from thine eyes.” This passage immediately precedes the prediction of the destruction of Jerusalem— In the interval between the services I had visits from Chief Justice Marshall, and judge Story, and also from the Commandeur, Torlade d’Azambuja: chargé d’Affaires of the usurper Don Miguel of Portugal— He arrived here just before the close of the last Administration, and was received as the representative of the Government de facto of Portugal, by President Jackson very shortly after his inauguration. He visited me first at Meridian Hill, and has repeated his visits, once at least every winter from that time— Don Miguel is now expelled from his throne and from his Country— Mr Torlade professes to believe in the doctrine of the Sovereignty of the People— He entertains the opinion that according to the Portuguese Constitution, Don Miguel is the rightful Sovereign of the kingdom, and also that he is the preferred favourite of the People of Portugal— But his elder brother Don Pedro, who was sometime Emperor of Brazil, but finally left that Country and returned to Europe, abdicated the crown of Portugal in favour of his daughter Donna Maria de Gloria, and as Regent of the kingdom, succeeded in expelling Don Miguel, with the Aid of his Alliance with Great-Britain.— Mr Torlade’s present situation here is an uncomfortable one— He is a sensible, and seems to be a very good man; worthy of a better master, and a better fate.

10. V:30. Monday.— At the House, a Message was received from the President, with a Report from the Secretary of State, and copies of Instructions and other papers, relative to the trade
between the United States, and the Islands of Cuba and of Porto Rico— This Message was in answer to a Resolution of the House of the 14th. of last Month, adopted at the motion of H. L. Pinckney of South-Carolina, made on the 24th. of last December— This was the regular day, for the reception of Memorials and Petitions; but the Speaker gave the floor to James H. Gholson of Virginia, to make a Speech in opposition to that of John M. Patton, made last Monday against the Resolutions of the Legislature of Virginia, which had been presented by William F. Gordon— I asked the Speaker to allow the States to be called over for Petitions and Memorials—stating that I had Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts to offer, and promising not to consume the time of the House in debating them— Gholson offered to suspend his remarks to give me an opportunity to present the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts, but Samuel M’Dowell Moore, objected, and came to my Seat to tell me, that they must get out their Speeches in reply to Patton— The Elections to the Legislature of Virginia, are to take place in the course of the next month, and the influence of Patton’s Speech upon them, is so terrific, that it must be counteracted, or all will be lost— Gholson therefore proceeded, till near 2. O’Clock, and was followed by M’Dowell Moore; both in Speeches to sustain the Resolutions of the Legislature of Virginia, but both shackled by their Jeffersonian creed— Then succeeded H. L Pinckney of South-Carolina, in defence of his State against Patton’s charge of rashness in her recent councils and measures.— Pinckney talks much nullification, and indulges himself in bitter invective against Andrew Jackson— All the members of the House from South-Carolina, excepting one of the nullification School; and so fanatical in their devotion to it, that they cannot resist the temptation to introduce it into all their Speeches; the consequence of which has been the forfeiture of every particle of their influence in the house. Pinckney who is a very able and eloquent and pious man, raved till have past 3 O’Clock, when the house adjourned, leaving his Speech unfinished— Spent the Evening with my wife, and Son, and his wife, in playing a rubber of whist.
11. V. Tuesday.

At the meeting of the House I moved the House for leave to present the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts respecting the removal of the deposits of public monies from the Bank of the United States— Objection was made and I moved the suspension of the rule; and upon taking the vote there was no Quorum— The vote taken again stood 70 to 56—not two thirds for the suspension of the rule, and my motion of course failed— Reports from standing Committees received. Archer from the Committee of foreign Affairs reports a Resolution instructing the Committee to enquire into the expediency of purchasing Washington’s Library and papers to be deposited in the Department of State—adopted— Cave Johnson from the Committee of private Land claims reports an Amendment to a Bill before the Committee, and that the Committee be discharged from further Consideration of the Bill—to be laid on the Speakers table— After debate this was agreed to by the house— The Committee of Elections, by Claiborne ask leave to sit, during the Session of the house—granted. Clayton of Georgia gets the floor upon Mardis’s Resolution, two minutes before the expiration of the hour, and asks permission to continue. Polk objects, but the house by vote refuse to proceed to the orders of the day— Clayton proceeds and finishes— In this Speech Mr Clayton, made a frank and generous acknowledgment, that he had done wrong in his report on the Bank investigation of 1832. he expressed his regret that he had indulged himself in personal reflections injurious to fair and honourable men, in that report, and without naming any one in particular, made an apology to all whose feelings may have been wounded by it— After he finished Burges claimed the floor, but Polk moved to take up the Military Appropriation Bill—and succeeded. The House went into Committee of
the whole on the state of the Union, Wayne in the Chair— James I. M’Kay of North-Carolina, moved sundry reductions of the Appropriations, but without success— The Committee after getting about half through the Bill, rose and reported progress. About 4 O’Clock the House adjourned— I dined with Benjamin Gorham, and Edward Everett— Calhoun, Clay, Preston, Governor Lincoln, Commodore Morris, Mr Torlade, Adams and Buchanan of the British Legation were there—and Mr Silsbee— The Senators came in late— The President this day sent a message to the Senate, re-nominating the Government Directors, of the Bank of the United States, who had been rejected by that body, on the previous nomination. He intimates that if the Reasons of the Senate for rejecting them were their conduct as directors last year, he could not in conscience nominate any person who would not act in the same manner, and threatens to leave the places vacant—by making no nomination— The Senators, who were of our dinner party, were in a state of high excitement.
12. V:30. Wednesday.

James K. Polk, chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, to whom I had given, the Letter from the Postmaster General recommending that provision should be made for a Post-Office together with the Custom-house at Plymouth, returned me the Letter, and said that the Committee of Ways and Means, approved of the object, but declined proposing an Appropriation as I had requested, because the Bill for erecting the Custom-house was reported by the Committee of Commerce— He said he should propose to the House to postpone the Report of the Committee of Ways and Means, on the deposit and Bank questions till next Tuesday, and would not object to suspend the rule to allow me to present the Resolutions of the Massachusetts Legislature— At the meeting of the House, he moved that the Report and Resolutions of the Committee of Ways and Means, which had been made the special order for this day, should be postponed till next Tuesday; Wilde of Georgia, objected; and said that he was ready and desirous to address the House upon the subject now— A debate of two hours ensued, till Wilde withdrew his opposition to the postponement— M’Kennan of Pennsylvania moved that the postponement should be till next Tuesday week, but this the House refused—and voted the postponement till next Tuesday— I then asked leave to present the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts— Objection being made, I moved the suspension of the rule, for that purpose, which the House refused to grant— Polk then moved a Resolution, to make the Deposit and Bank report, the special order for every day at one O’Clock from next Tuesday till the decision of the House upon the Resolutions; Saturdays excepted; and Mondays for the reception of Memorials and Petitions— I objected to the reception of this motion, and Polk moved and carried a suspension of the Rule, that he should make it— The Speaker said the Resolution must lie over one day; upon which Polk moved a suspension of the rules again, that his motion might be considered now; and just carried it by two thirds 115 to 56— I opposed the Resolution, and an Amendment to it was moved by Vinton of Ohio; but the Speaker and the party had settled it otherwise, and Polk’s motion was accordingly driven through the House, with the exception only of the Saturday’s and Monday’s— Adjourned at 1/2 past three— I dined with Coll. Robert B. Campbell of South-Carolina, at his lodgings at Gadsby’s There was a party of upwards of 30 persons, including the whole delegation from South-Carolina in both Houses of Congress— James Blair one of the members is deeply at variance with all the rest being the only unionist and anti-nullifier of the delegation— He was reserved and silent. Coll. Campbell introduced to me Henry Laurens Pinckney, the new member from Charleston
who takes the place of Coll. Drayton— He is one of the most ardent of the nullification party. He spoke with much indignation of the Speaker Stevenson’s partiality this morning; to which he justly attributed the rejection of my motions for leave to present the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts.

13. V. Thursday.— I called on the Secretary of the Treasury, Taney, and enquired further respecting the Appropriation for a Post-Office at Plymouth— He thought there were difficulties in the case— And said it had not been the practice of the Government to provide Post-Offices— I asked him to write to me, certifying that there was no Appropriation for a Post-Office at New-York, and I should then satisfy my constituents that they cannot claim one: he said he would write to me; and that he should be against extending the principle any further.— At the House, after some preliminary business of routine, Mardis’s Resolution, about the Selection of the deposit Banks was resumed— Burges of Rhode-Island spoke till the expiration of the hour. Polk then moved to pass to the orders of the day, and that the House go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up the Army Appropriation Bill— Marshall of Kentucky claims the floor, for his unfinished Speech on the revolutionary commutation Bill; but Foot in the Speaker’s Chair gives the floor to Polk— The House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, Wayne in the Chair—Vance of Ohio—Seaborn Jones of Georgia—Sevier of Arkansas, make objections against parts of the Bill—to no purpose— M’Kay of North-Carolina withdrew his objections— Ashley of Missouri, objects—which leads to a long debate— Horace Everett, of Vermont moves an amendment to reduce the appropriation at Fort-Gibson, Arkansas from 25000 to 5000 dollars; which is carried— Polk agrees to sundry reductions of the Appropriations. After the Bill was gone through, Connor of North-Carolina, moved an additional Section to the Bill giving the privilege of franking to the Chief Engineer— This was opposed by me and others, and rejected— The Bill was reported with Amendments to the House, which immediately afterwards adjourned— General Aaron Ward of New-York, shewed me a Letter to him from Stevenson, the Speaker, who has written some verses in Ward’s daughter Emily’s Album— There was a flattering compliment to my verses in the same Album; which, as flattery always breeds good nature, I took as kindly intended in Stevenson, and thought he meant it as an atonement for his rough usage of me in the house.— My wife, with my Son John and his wife, and their children went this Evening to the Theatre, to hear Mr and Mrs Wood.

14. V. Friday.— Mardis’s Resolution came up— Mr Burges proceeded a few minutes in his Speech, but being hoarse and quite unwell, Elisha Whittlesey moved the postponement of the subject till next week; the House however without deciding the question, at the expiration of the hour passed to the orders of the day— Polk moved the suspension of the rule to take up the army appropriation Bill; but he could not obtain a majority of two thirds.— A considerable number of Bills at the third reading were passed— Then Polk repeated his motion to suspend the rule and take up the army appropriation Bill, which was again rejected— After the passage of another Bill from the Senate, he made the motion a third time, and called for the yeas and nays— M’Kennan moved to include the Bill making an Appropriation for the repair of the Cumberland Road, to which Polk assented, but Ewing required a vote upon each Bill separately— The rule was suspended for the Army Appropriation Bill 126 to 62 and the suspension was refused for the Cumberland Road-Bill 94 to 91— The Army Bill was taken up— The Amendments to the Bill reported by the Committee of the
whole, were all concurred in by the House, excepting one making an Appropriation of an extra allowance to Dr Beaumont, a Surgeon in the Army, of 1 dollar 25 cents a day from the 1st. of January 1831. amounting to 1825 dollars, which after being debated till half past 3. was rejected by yeas and nays 56 to 129. On the amendment reducing the appropriation at Fort Gibson from 25000 to 5000 dollars, Sevier the Delegate from Arkansas, opposed the concurrence of the House, with the Amendment, and proposed one of his own, which was rejected— The bill being gone through, Seaborn Jones of Georgia, moved a proviso that the Appropriations for barracks should be confined to the purchase of materials—rejected— The bill passed to be engrossed— The Speaker sent me a Letter from Walter Jones, enquiring if the use of the Hall could be obtained for Tuesday Evening, 7. O’Clock, for the delivery of an Eulogy upon the late William Wirt, by Samuel L. Southard— Just before the Adjournment of the House, I made the motion, and it was unanimously adopted.— Mr Stanbury gave me his short minutes of my Speech of yesterday, with a request that I would write it out for the National Intelligencer— I began it accordingly, this Evening.
15. V. Saturday.

Morning visits from Mr Chilton Allan of Kentucky who introduced to me his Son, and from Aaron Vanderpoel of Kinderhoek New-York. At the House the Speaker read a Letter from Tristam Burges, stating that he was prevented by indisposition, from attending the House this day, and requesting the postponement of Mardis’s Resolution, upon which he was speaking, which was accordingly done— The rule of private business was suspended, and the army appropriation Bill was taken up and passed.— Then the rule was again suspended and Speight’s joint Resolution with an Appropriation was taken up at the third reading— There was an Amendment proposed by Speight, to strike out the whole Resolution, and turn it into a mere Resolution of the House, directing the payment to be made from the contingent fund of the House. The Speaker pronounced this not in order— Foster of Georgia moved that the Resolution be committed to the Committee on the Library, with instructions to enquire the amount of the cost of the Books to be purchased, under the Resolution— I opposed the commitment of the Resolution, on the ground that the Resolution itself was unconstitutional, as containing an Appropriation— The Speaker pronounced me not in order, and after some contest I submitted to his decision— Foster asked for the yeas and nays upon his motion, but they were refused, and his motion was rejected. Speights amendment then came up, and the Speaker said I might now make my objection— I did object the unconstitutionality of an Appropriation of money by a joint Resolution— Speight replied by renewing the proposition to convert the joint Resolution into a separate one, and direct the payment from the contingent fund of the House. M’Duffie moved that it should remain a joint Resolution, striking out the Appropriation—but this was rejected. Pinckney of South-Carolina moved the indefinite postponement of the subject, which was also rejected by yeas and nays 78 to 114— M’Duffie moved an Amendment, that the Volumes of the Register of Debates, furnished to the members, should be deposited into the Library when the
present members retire, for the use of their Successors—rejected— Polk who opposed the Resolution, read a Statement which he had procured from Walter Lowrie, Secretary of the Senate, of their contingent expenses for the present Session, which he represented as enormous— I remarked sharply upon the impropriety of a member of one house of Congress applying privately to the Clerk of the other, for statements to raise charges against the House itself to which the Clerk belonged—and asked what the House would think if an individual Senator should apply to our Clerk, for Statements of our expenditures of the contingent fund, and should read those Statements in the Senate, to support a charge of extravagance against the house— Polk was so ashamed of what he had done, that he made no reply, but the joke was that his Statement produced the directly opposite effect to what he intended, and promoted the passage of the Resolution It passed as a separate Resolution—payment to be made from the contingent fund of the House. I thus succeeded in preventing the passage of a joint Resolution with an Appropriation— But Stevenson the Speaker, from ignorance, or carelessness had suffered it to go to a third reading even without reference to a Committee of the whole, and when I asked him whether an Appropriation could be made by Resolution, answered yes— Upon such Slender threads hang the vital principles of our Constitution— There was some sparring between Wise of Virginia and Mann of New-York— Adjourned 1/2 past 3.— We had company, named in the margin under the dash, to dine— And in the Evening, the family went to the Theatre.
16. V. Sunday.

At St. John’s Church— In the morning heard Mr Hawley, read Prayers for the fifth Sunday in Lent, and preach from Romans 8.6. [“]For, to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.” This is the theme, which Mr Smith of the Presbyterian Church, diluted last Spring into six Sermons. Mr Hawley is more compendious— He gave notice that the Sacrament of the Lord’s Supper would be administered on Easter-Sunday; this day fortnight— I had visits after the morning service from Mr Binney and Mr Peters— The Supreme Court of the United States, are about closing their Session, and Mr Peters, their Reporter, returns to Philadelphia— Mrs Frye was also here— After dinner there was no service at the Presbyterian Church, and I attended again at St. John’s— Mr Hawley’s discourse was from Revelation 1.10 “I was in the Spirit on the Lord’s day, and heard behind me a great voice as of a trumpet 11. Saying, I am Alpha and Omega, the first and the last:”—the rest of the verse is, “and what thou seest, write in a book, and send it unto the seven churches which are in Asia; unto Ephesus, and unto Smyrna and unto Peragamos, and unto Thyatira, and unto Sardis, and unto Philadelphia and unto Laodicea.”— This subject is too pregnant of comment to be disposed of in one of Mr Hawley’s afternoon Sermons— The Book of Revelation though in form only an Epistle from the Evangelist John to the seven Churches of Asia, is the only avowed prophetical Book of the New Testament—different in Style from all the rest—mystical—obscure—and sublime— There has been some question made of its authenticity, and the malignant maniac Alexander Smyth, one morning certified upon honour that he had discovered it was written by Cerinthus. There is something contagious in the operation of the Apocalypse upon weak minds.

17. V:45. Monday.— William Jackson took his seat as representative of the 9th. Congressional District of Massachusetts—to which after a long struggle, andabortive trials, he has been chosen, in opposition to Henry A. S. Dearborn, who lost the confidence of his Constituents, by an ambidexter course of conduct, on the Masonic and Anti-masonic controversy.
Mr Nathan Appleton, who was the member of the House from Boston, in the last Congress, but is now here as a member of a deputation from certain memorialists in that City upon the Bank and Deposit questions, was in the House— It was the regular day for the reception of Memorials and Petitions, and H. L. Pinckney, who had the floor since last Monday for an unfinished nullification Speech upon the Resolutions of the Virginia Legislature, presented by Gordon, after some discussion consented to yield the floor, for the order of the day. The States were called, beginning with Maine; whence several Memorials were presented— One by the Speaker, from 8 persons of Portland, complaining of having been misrepresented by F. O. J. Smith—who replied by a Speech in justification of himself— When Massachusetts was called, I presented the Resolutions of the Legislature, upon the Currency, and the removal of the Public Deposits from the Bank of the United States, with a very few remarks; touching somewhat personally upon the President—and I moved that they should be read, printed, and laid on the table to be referred to a select Committee with Instructions to report a plan for continuing to the People the advantages resulting from a National Bank— Polk started up, and fell into an idolizing and mawkish glorification of Doctor Andrew Jackson, with some coarse and equally dull invective against me— I rose and said I should not reply to his Speech; and gave notice once for all, that whenever any admirer of the President of the United States, should think fit to pay his court to him in the House, either by a flaming Panegyric upon him, or by a rancorous invective upon me, he should never elicit one word of reply from me

lg.l: “No!— let the candied tongue, lick absurd pomp,
And crook the pregnant hinges of the knee,

div.p: Polk, shrunk back abashed into his shell, and said not a word— The lines from Hamlet struck the House like a spark of electricity; and D. J. Pearce said to me laughing that if Polk had not enough of that, he was too unreasonable— Benjamin Gorham presented the Memorial from Boston, with some remarks— Motion to print the names of the subscribers to the memorial contested and debated— Jones of Georgia moved that the part of the motion to print, including the names should be laid on the Table, and called for the yeas and nays— Rejected—79 to 106. Then the printing was carried again by yeas and nays 108 to 78. Levi Lincoln presented the Worcester County Memorial and Resolutions, with a handsome introduction— Horace Everett presented the proceedings of a Convention in the County of Windsor, Vermont, against the removal of the deposit, and in favour of their restoration— Millard Fillmore, a Memorial from Buffalo, New-York, whereupon Abijah Mann observed that there was a Branch of the Bank of the United States at Buffalo— Various other Petitions and Memorials were presented, till Vinton of Ohio moved to adjourn; which was carried— In the Evening I went with my family to the Theatre, to see and hear Mr and Mrs Wood— The performances were the Lottery Ticket, and Cinderella the farce was performed first.— The Opera was Italian Music with English words— Mr and Mrs Wood have good voices, but are rather indifferent performers— Mrs Wood especially fat, fair, and forty, is far too heavy a personage for the part of Cinderella— My Son John has been highly delighted with her singing of certain popular and sentimental Songs—particularly one of which the Irish words Savourneen deelish form a part— He repeats these words so often, and with so much feeling, that I surmise, there is something in the song that that affects him, more than the music of Mrs Wood’s voice.

18. V. Tuesday. At the House, numerous reports were made from the standing Committees, upon subjects not of general interest— A Message was received from the President, with a Report from the Secretary of State, and a letter from the Commissioners under the Neapolitan Treaty, and a recommendation to Congress to extend the term allowed to the Commissioners for the performance of their duties— The documents communicated by the President, relating to the trade with Cuba and Porto Rico, were at the motion of H. L. Pinckney referred to the Committee of Commerce with instructions to inquire into the discriminating duties in those Islands, and the expediency of countervailing them— The first hour was chiefly consumed by Mr Burges in speaking upon Mardis’s Resolution Burges did not finish— At one the special order of the day was taken up— The Report of the Committee of Ways and Means, on the Deposits and the Bank— The first Resolution appended to the Report is that the Bank of the United States ought not to be rechartered— Wilde of Georgia asked Polk whether he wished to speak upon the Report— Polk answered no. Wilde then moved to amend the first Resolution reported by the Committee; by adding theretoAnd that the reasons assigned by the Secretary of the Treasury for removing the public deposits from the Bank of the United States are unsatisfactory and insufficient— Upon this, Mr Wilde spoke till 4 O’Clock, when he yielded to a motion for adjournment, without finishing— Adjourned— I went to the Senate Chamber, but they were adjourning. Mr Webster’s Bill for rechartering the Bank for six years, was this day presented, and supported by him in a Speech of two hours—followed by Benjamin Watkins Leigh of Virginia, who said he must vote against rechartering the Bank now, but might vote otherwise hereafter— Stansbury the Reporter came to me with his minutes of my Speech yesterday; on presenting the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts, which I revised and corrected— He wanted them, to have them published in the Intelligencer of to-morrow Morning— At seven this Evening, at the Capitol, in the Hall of the House of Representatives, Samuel L. Southard delivered by appointment of the members of the Bar of the Supreme Court of the United States, an Eulogy upon the late William Wirt.— He was two hours and ten minutes in the delivery— The Hall was well filled. Many Ladies— The Judges of the Supreme Court of the United States—but not one of the Heads of the Executive Departments— I took Dr Huntt home— It was near eleven when I reached my own— Received from William S Archer an invitation to dine with him next Friday at Dowson’s.

19. VI:30. Wednesday. The morning was shortened by my rising from an hour and a half to two hours later than my usual time— They were borrowed last Evening, by the performance at the Capitol— At the House, Elisha Whittlesey from the Committee of Claims reported a Resolution, to instruct that same Committee to inquire into the expediency of referring by Law to the 3d. Auditor, all claims for buildings destroyed by the Enemy during the last War—and also of providing by Law for the Settlement of all claims for loss of property in the military Service, since the last War—this Resolution was adopted— Edward Everett moved a call upon the Secretary of War for information recently received respecting the fortifications proposed to be built on Castle Island in Boston harbour, and at Throg’s next in the State of New-York; which by unanimous consent was considered and agreed to— On motion of C. C. Clay, the Report from the Commissioner of the General Land Office, which accompanied the President’s Message at the commencement of the Session, was reformed to the Committee on the
Public Lands— Then Mr Burges took up the remainder of the first hour upon Mardis’s Resolution, without finishing his Speech— He told me he should want not exceeding two Morning’s more— It is a very extraordinary practice, used I believe in no other Assembly save the House of Representatives of the United States, to deliver a long, elaborate and studied Speech, by driblets of a half an hour a day— At one O’Clock the special order of the day was called R. H. Wilde resumed and concluded his Speech, which was learned, ingenious, eloquent, and full of sarcastic humour.— When he closed, W. W. Ellsworth of Connecticut and H. L. Pinckney of South-Carolina rose for the floor— Pinckney obtained it and moved the adjournment at 1/2 past 3.— I dined at Mr Silsbee’s, with I. C. Bates, W. Baylies, George N. Briggs George Grennell, Levi Lincoln, G. P. Osgood, Willie P. Mangum, W. R. King, of Alabama, Samuel L. Southard and Alexander Porter of Louisiana—the four last members of the Senate.
20. V. Thursday.

Morning visit from Mr Nathan Appleton and Mr Thomas Motley of Boston— They are here as members of a deputation from the Boston Memorialists for the restoration of the Deposits and in favour of the Bank of the United States— I was a little surprized and much on finding the tendency of Mr Appleton’s conversation decidedly against the Bank, and in no wise favourable to the ostensible object of his mission— In the last Congress I had considered Mr Appleton, as a very equivocal friend to the Bank of the United States, and Edward Everett had told me that Appleton had a large interest in one of the State Banks, rivals to that Institution— He took however no active part against the Bank of the United States— His Patriotism was all concentrated in the Cotton Manufactures— Where his Treasure was, there was his heart also— But his acceptance of this mission, and his manner of executing its duties gives me as slender an opinion of his personal integrity as of his political morals.— At the House, Horace Binney, came to my Seat, and enquired, whether it might not be advisable to move the recommitment of the third of the four Resolutions reported by the Committee of Ways and Means— This Resolution is, that the State Banks ought to be continued as the places of deposits of the public money, and that it is expedient for Congress to make further provision by Law, prescribing the mode of Selection, the securities to be taken, and the manner and terms on which they are to be employed— Mr Binney’s proposal was to move the recommitments for the Committee to report a regulating Bill— I told him I thought the motion to recommit would not succeed, and that their regulating Bill, if they should report one, would not be worth a straw— Binney did not make the motion for recommitment.— The petition from Massachusetts, for the improvement of Taunton river, was at the motion of Joseph M. Harper of New Hampshire transferred from the Committee of Commerce to the Committee of Roads and Canals— Sutherland chairman of the Committee of Commerce, reported two light house Bills, a harbor Bill amended, and a Bill to make Dorchester in the State of Massachusetts a Port of Delivery—all referred to Committees of the whole— Mr Burges continued his Speech upon Mardis’s Resolution till one O’Clock, when the special order of the day was called, and Henry L. Pinckney made his Speech in favour of Wildes proposed amendment to the first of the four Resolutions reported by the Committee of Ways and Means— While Pinckney was speaking James Blair of South-Carolina came, and
took a seat near and in face of him, looking steadily and intently at him for some time— And at the moment when Pinckney said that the whole South, was united against the removal of the Deposits, Blair with a loud voice exclaimed “Its a lie.”— There was a momentary pause— Pinckney stop’d, and said—“I claim the Protection of the House.”— No movement was made by the House— One of the members friendly to Blair, went round to the seat where he was and whispered to him; upon which Blair rose, and went with him out of the house— Pinckney had already resumed, his Speech, which he concluded without appearing to have been at all disconcerted by this singular interruption— Blair is an honest and very intelligent man ruined by habits of intemperance and maddened with opium.

21. V. Friday. At the House, upon the motion of William H. Ashley of Missouri, the Committee of the whole House were discharged from the consideration of two Bills, which had been referred to them, one for the continuation of the Cumberland road, from the river Mississippi to the city of Jefferson in the State of Missouri, and one, for the survey and location of the Cumberland road, from Vandalia, in the State of Illinois, to the Mississippi, and the Bills, were committed to the Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union— There is by the rules of the House a distinction between a Committee of the whole House, and a Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union—the latter being reserved for subjects considered of the highest importance— It is always in order to move to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, and it always has precedence in point of time, over the ordinary Committees of the whole House— The practice, with the ordinary routine of Bills, when they are reported, to read them a first and second time, by their titles, which is a constructive reading, and refer them to the Committee of the Whole House, and make them the order of the day for to-morrow— But this to-morrow, for multitudes of Bills never comes— It is to-morrow, and to-morrow and to-morrow—for the Bills thus referred must when the House go into Committee of the whole be taken up in the order of their commitment, and there are many which the Committee never reach— Ashley’s motive therefore in getting the two Bills transferred from the Committee of the whole House, to the Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union, was to obtain for them a chance of being considered, at the present Session of Congress.— This Cumberland Road, from Vandalia, in the State of Illinois to the Mississippi, and from the Mississippi, to the City of Jefferson, in the State of Missouri—how it sounds! what a demonstration of the gigantic growth of this Country in population and in power is contained in these few words—and how insignificant in comparison with them is the subject which occupied the whole time of both Houses of Congress this day— In the House, Mr Burges consumed the first hour with another driblet of his Speech upon Mardis’s Resolution— Then George R. Gilmer of Georgia made a Speech of an hour and a half against the amendment proposed by his Colleague Wilde, to the first Resolution reported by the Committee of Ways and Means.— After which C. C. Clay of Alabama took the floor and the House adjourned. I went into the Senate chamber, and heard Thomas H. Benton of Missouri till 4. O’Clock— I then called on Mr Rembrandt Peale, and agreed to give him a sitting, next Tuesday, at half past ten— Thence, I went and dined with William S. Archer at Dowson’s— The company consisted of Sir Charles Vaughan, the British Minister, with his Secretaries William Pitt Adams, and Buchanan, B. Gorham, Edward Everett, B. W. Leigh, Calhoun, Preston, Dunlap, John H. Fulton, Mrs Preston, &c.— Home about 9. P.M.

22. VI. Saturday. At the House— Mr Burges continued his Speech on Mardis’s Resolution till the expiration of the first hour— Then there was a call of the House to make a Quorum— Then M’Kim of Maryland moved to suspend the rule of private business, to take up the Bill making Appropriations for continuing the Cumberland road, in Ohio, Indiana and Illinois, and repairing the same road, East of the Ohio, and continuing certain territorial roads for the year 1834— To this were added at the motion of others, and accepted by M’Kim, the Bill authorising the construction of a Bridge across the Potomac, and repealing all former acts, relating thereto—and the Bill for the continuation of the Cumberland road, from the Mississippi river to the city of Jefferson, in the State of Missouri— Parker of New-Jersey demanded that the question should be taken separately upon each Bill— But the vote of two thirds, to suspend the rule could not be obtained upon either of the Bills— The yeas and nays upon the first were 104 to 85—upon the second 102 to 81— The motion for suspending the rule upon the third was then withdrawn, and after a waste of about two hours upon this abortive attempt to smother the consideration of private business, on the only day of the week now left for that part of the duties of the House, the private Bills were taken up. A Bill for remitting the impost duties upon certain marble Sculptures to ornament an Exchange building at Philadelphia, was vehemently debated—supported with great earnestness by Horace Binney—opposed by Millard Fillmore of New-York, Dutee J. Pearce of Rhode-Island, and several others, and finally rejected 41 to 135. I could scarcely comprehend the bitterness of opposition with which it was hunted down— Immediately after this exploit, at 1/2 past two the House adjourned— I went into the Senate chamber, but they were going into conclave upon Executive business— I took refuge in the Library, and there read in Tait’s Magazine a violent invective against the English University of Cambridge— I dined at Mr Poor’s, with John Reed, George Evans—and Saml L. Southard. Governor Lincoln and Mr Gardiner of Hallowell, Maine, were there—Mrs Evans, and Miss Virginia Southard.— Home between 8. and 9.

23. V:30. Sunday.— Morning Service at the Presbyterian Church. Heard Mr Smith from 1. Peter 1.4. [“]To an inheritance incorruptible, and undefiled, and that fadeth not away, reserved in heaven for you 5 Who are kept by the power of God through faith unto Salvation, ready to be revealed in the last time”— Mr Southard, Dr. Arnold Naudain a member of the Senate from the State of Delaware, and Daniel Wardwell a member of the House of Representatives from the State of New-York, were in the pew, and Dr Naudain told me he would come and introduce to me Mr Courtney, a Lecturer upon Astronomy— In the afternoon at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley, read the Evening Prayer, for the Sunday before Easter, or Palm-Sunday; and an Irishman named M’Calla, preached from Zechariah 9.12. “Turn you to the strong hold, ye prisoners of hope: even to-day do I declare that I will render double unto thee”—a sensible discourse; rather long; and delivered with a large portion of the brogue. Mary-Louisa was with me, morning and afternoon.
24. V. Monday

Dr Naudain came this morning, and introduced to me Mr Courtney, a strolling Lecturer upon Astronomy, who solicited my Subscription to a course of Lectures which he is about to deliver here, and I gave it—though it may probably not be in my convenience or inclination to attend one of the Lectures— With such an introduction it was scarcely possible to decline the Subscription, but this is one of the common modes of beggary practiced in this Country— At the House it was the weekly day for the reception of Memorials and Petitions— Henry L. Pinckney had the floor, for the remnant of a nullification Speech upon Wilde’s amendment, but he was not in the house. Schley of Georgia, was also in labour with a Speech, but the Speaker Stevenson denied him the
floor— So the Petitions and Memorials were called—beginning with the State of New-York, where they had ceased at the adjournment last Monday— 167 memorials and petitions were now presented, upwards of sixty of which were for and against the removal of the deposits and the rechartering of the Bank of the United States. Almost all the Memorials from New-York, New-Jersey and Pennsylvania were upon this subject— H. Binney presented the proceedings of several Meetings, and Memorials, from Tradesmen and Meckanics of every description, all bitterly complaining of distress and praying for the restoration of the deposits and the recharter of the Bank of the United States— Mr Binney upon presenting these papers made a few explanatory remarks— Then Watmough followed with certain proceedings of Meetings, and Memorials, of the same complection, from his, the third Congressional District of Pennsylvania—one of the Memorials complained of a fraudulent exaggeration of the numbers signed to a memorial from the same District, against the Bank of the United States, and heretofore presented by Joel B. Sutherland.— This produced a skirmish of debate between Sutherland, Watmough and Binney— Sutherland retorts the charge of repetitions and duplicate names, against the Memorials presented by Watmough and Binney, and says that such accidents will sometimes happen in the best of families.— Mutual explanations follow, and Sutherland comes off without much discomfiture— Seaborn Jones of Georgia, presented to the House an accord and explanation between Henry L. Pinckney and James Blair— The difference being adjusted honourably to both parties, and the friendly relations between them restored. The Speaker presented the proceedings of a meeting in York County, Pennsylvania, approving the removal of the deposites, and against the recharter of the Bank of the United States— The leading subscriber to these proceedings was Adam King, Editor of a Newspaper, and a member of the last Congress. Charles A. Barnitz the present member from the District presented a protest against these proceedings, declaring that they were not adopted at the meeting; and that a majority of the Meeting were opposed to them and voted against them— All the papers Pro and con, lie on the table— Sundry other Memorials were presented.— Parker presented two Resolutions of the Legislature of New-Jersey, dated the 21st. of February, confirming and reiterating others passed on the 11th. of January, approving the measures of the President, and the course of Mr Taney, in removing the Government deposites.— Jeremiah M’Lene of Ohio presented a Resolution of the Legislature of that State, soliciting a speedy decision on their Memorial, respecting the boundary line, between that State, and the Territory of Michigan—lies on the table—also three Resolutions of the same Legislature declaring the Military Academy at West-Point partial in its operations and wholly inconsistent with the spirit and genius of our liberal institutions: that it ought to be abolished, and instructing the Senators and requesting the Representatives from Ohio in Congress to oppose any further operations for its support, with a proviso that no representative should be considered as requested to vote against the known wishes of his Constituents—and that the Governor should transmit copies of these Resolutions to the Senators and Representatives of the State in Congress.— The Speaker proceeded in calling the States, till he came to Mississippi; and prevented Lytle of Ohio, from making a Speech on a Memorial presented by him— Cage of Mississippi presented Memorials from Wilkinson and Adams Counties in that State, disapproving the removal of the deposites, and praying that they may be restored, and that the Bank of the United States may be rechartered. Cage proposed to comment upon these Memorials, but the Speaker interdicted him— Plummer
rose and asked leave of the Speaker to make a Speech on the Memorials presented by Cage— The Speaker refused— Plummer asked a suspension of the rule, and insists upon taking the question— Plummers motion was rejected; but there was no semblance of a Quorum— A motion for a call of the House was rejected— Two successive motions were made to adjourn, and at 5 O’Clock the adjournment was carried by yeas and nays 24 to 21—only 45 members voting— Consumed the evening with my family at whist.
25. VI. Tuesday.

This Morning, by leave of the House sundry Memorials and Petitions were presented, which there was not time to receive yesterday. I presented the petition of Relief Harris; called up from the last Session, when it had been presented 12. December 1832—and with the papers accompanying it, had it referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions— Lytle of Ohio made an attempt to appeal from the Speaker’s decision yesterday, interdicting him from speaking on the memorial presented by him— The Speaker now decided that it was too late for him to appeal—much to Lytle’s annoyance.— Plummer renewed his application for leave to speak against Cage’s Resolutions, and after some altercation with the Speaker moved that Cage’s Resolutions should be referred to the Committee of Ways and Means, with Instructions to report Resolutions, adverse to the prayer of the Memorials. The hour was so nearly absorbed in this petty warfare, that Mr Burges declined proceeding upon his Speech on Mardis’s Resolution— The Speaker laid before the House a Letter from Lieutenant Uriah P. Levy of the Navy of the United States, offering as a present, a colossal bronze Statue of Thomas Jefferson, executed at Paris by the celebrated David and Honoré Gonou which communication was referred to the Committee on the Library— At one the special order of the day was called and C. C. Clay of Alabama made a Speech of two hours against Wilde’s Amendment, and to the glorification of President Jackson—he was personally abusive upon Wilde, and upon me. Clay is a man of some talents, and of much activity and perseverance: a fluent Speaker of very little power; but making up the deficiency of substance, by the ardour of his zeal— So it is with almost all the Jackson leaders in the House— After Clay had finished, about 3 O’Clock the House adjourned— Mr William Clarke of Pennsylvania, proposed to me to attend a meeting of the Antimasonic members of the House at which MrGranger of New-York, now in the City will be present, and that the Meeting should be in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures—for which I named next Thursday Evening at seven O’Clock— I spoke to Harvey Bestor to have the chamber prepared— I enquired of Mr Binney; if there had ever been reported to Congress, reasons for making deposits of public monies otherwise than in the Bank of the United States and its branches; before this case of Roger B. Taney— He said once, by W H. Crawford, which I found was on the 10th. of December 1817.— See Also, the Act of Congress of 10 May 1800. Laws 21. S. Vol. 3. p 385. and Resolution of 30. April 1816— While we were this Evening playing a rubber of whist, Mr Southard, the Senator from New-Jersey came, and introduced to me nineteen young men from Philadelphia, being part of the deputation from the Meeting of young man in that City who have memorialized Congress and the President on the removal of the deposits, the Bank of the United States, the distress, and the currency.

26. V.30. Wednesday.— Letters received—one from Solomon Lincoln of Hingham, concerning the payment of Pensioners for the half year ending the 4th. of September last; and not
called for, till after the order from the Secretary of War to the Bank of the United States and its branches, not to pay the Pensions— I called upon the Secretary of War, and read to him the passage of Mr Lincoln’s Letter.— He took a minute of it, and promised to send me an answer in writing to-morrow— At the House Mr Burges concluded his Speech upon the Mardis Resolution, with the hour, and Chilton Allan of Kentucky took the floor for to-morrow. On Wilde’s Amendment, Schley of Georgia made a Speech of three hours against the Bank of the United States and the restoration of the deposits— When he finished William W. Ellsworth, took the floor and moved to adjourn— Opposition was made—the yeas and nays were called and the adjournment was refused 64 to 66— Augustin S. Clayton of Georgia then moved a call of the House and demanded the yeas and nays— The call commenced but was soon arrested by another motion to adjourn, made by M’Comas of Virginia which was carried by yeas and nays 70 to 62— Evening much occupied in preparing to address the House, upon the removal of the deposites.
27. V:30. Thursday.

I had this morning a number of visitors, but could not retain their names— Chiefly members of the numerous deputations from Meetings in several of our Cities, sent to represent to Congress, and to the President, the great distress among all the industrious classes of the community, in consequence of the harsh and unlawful measures of the President against the Bank of the United States— It is scarcely conceivable that such extensive desolation should have been effected, by so very trifling a cause.— At the House, Chilton Allan of Kentucky spoke upon the Mardis Resolution till one— And William W. Ellsworth of Connecticut, upon Wilde’s Amendment about two hours.— Rufus Choate then took the floor and moved an adjournment— Isaac M’Kim of Baltimore called for the yeas and nays, and the adjournment was carried 86 to 67.— At 7 in the Evening, I attended the meeting of the Anti-Masonic Members of the House of Representatives which was transferred from the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures to that of the Committee of Foreign Affairs— There were present, John Banks, William Clarke, Harmar Denny, and William Hiester of Pennsylvania, John Dickson, Millard Fillmore, Philo C. Fuller, Abner Hazeltine Henry C. Martindale, and Frederic Whittlesey of New-York, Jonathan Sloane of Ohio, William Slade of Vermont; and William Jackson of Massachusetts— I was chosen chairman of the Meeting, which had been agreed upon by the members from New-York and Pennsylvania. Its purpose was to hold a consultation upon the present condition and prospects of the Antimasonic cause, in the several States where it has partially prevailed, and to enquire whether any concert of measures might be advisable for its promotion.— The Occasion of the Meeting was the presence of Mr Grainger of New-York in the City, and he was present at the Meeting— Nothing special was proposed, but Mr Grainger was requested to give a statement of the condition of Antimasonry in the State of New-York, and especially in that part of it where he resides.— He said that in all the Western Counties of New-York Masonry was extinct— The lodges and Chapters were all abandoned, and almost all of them formally dissolved.— That the Spirit of Antimasonry had consequently subsided; there was no adversary left to contend with, and as a distinctive party there could scarcely be said to be any anti-masonry left— If the Free-Masons should attempt to revive their Institutions in those Counties, he had no doubt, the Antimasonic Spirit would instantly revive, with as much zeal and ardour as it had ever manifested
but Masonry was no longer a subject upon which there was a conflict of opinion to stimulate exertion, and as a distinct principle it would be utterly impossible to maintain a mere antimasonic party— The members of the House from the State of New-York all agreed that this was perfectly in harmony with the prevailing Sentiments of their Constituents— All were of opinion that it would be impossible to maintain any longer in that State a distinct, organized Anti-masonic party— The members from Pennsylvania, appeared to be not quite so much discouraged; but none of them entertained any expectation that the party would obtain a majority of the People of the State— After a desultory conversation, of between two and three hours the meeting was by common consent adjourned; to meet again on Tuesday the 15th. of April at 7 in the Evening, and at the same place. It was near eleven at Night when I got home.
28. V:45. Friday

Mrs Smith called to visit her Sister— At the House James W. Bouldin a brother of the member who died suddenly while addressing the House in his place on the 11th. of last Month, and elected to supply his place, took his Seat.— I offered a Resolution to call upon the Secretary of the Treasury, for returns relating to the Deposit Banks— The Resolution was received by unanimous consent— I asked the House to consider it now— Objection was made by James M. Wayne of Georgia— Jesse Speight of North-Carolina said there was a document laid on our tables this morning containing the information that my Resolution required— I answered that it did not— After some discussion I consented that the Resolution should lay over till to-morrow, and be printed, with the understanding that it shall then be taken up— Some other Resolutions were introduced— Then Chilton Allan talked out the remnant of the hour upon Mardis’s Resolution— And then on Wilde’s Amendment, Choate spoke an hour and a half, arguing to the majority, friends and supporters of the Administration, that the restoration of the deposites is a measure of high interest and true policy to them. It was the most eloquent Speech of the Session, and in a course of reasoning altogether impressive and original— But seed sown at broadcast which will take no root in the soil— Choate is a young man, of great power and promise, whose political career has been short but brilliant— His health is indifferent and he has a cadaverous look— He proposes to resign his Seat in Congress which interferes too much with the profits of his practice at the bar— He was this day followed by Philemon Dickerson of New-Jersey for about three quarters of an hour, in every respect a contrast to the eloquence of Choate—dulness personified— Hardin of Kentucky, obtained the floor and moved an adjournment as a personal indulgence to himself; not being prepared with is documents— Adjourned by yeas and nays 82 to 69.— The House on the motion of John M’Kinley of Alabama, agreed to meet from this time forward at eleven in the morning— The Senate this day took the questions on two Resolutions offered by Henry Clay of Kentucky. 1. Censuring the President of the United States for usurpation of Power in his late measures—passed by a vote of 26 to 20. 2. That the reasons of the Secretary of the Treasury, for removing the deposites are insufficient 28 to 18— Chambers of Maryland, and Bell of New-Hampshire absent— They would have voted for both the Resolutions— The first of these Resolutions ought in my opinion not to have passed, and I gave it very fully and with much earnestness to Nathan Silsbee, and to Samuel L. Southard who at different times consulted me concerning it— They did nevertheless both vote for it, under the domineering influence of Mr Clay— My time was absorbed this Evening on various researches.
29. III:30. Saturday.

Morning crowded with researches for information upon the subjects of discussion before the house, at the meeting of which, immediately after the reading of the Journal, I called up my Resolution; which I modified, by adding to it the Resolution that I offered on the 6th of this month, as follows—[“]Resolved that the Secretary of the Treasury be directed to lay before this House, copies of the charters of all the Banks selected by him as depositories of the public moneys in the place of the Bank of the United States and its branches; together with the names of the Presidents, Cashiers, Directors and Stockholders in the said selected Banks, and the names of the lawyers and Solicitors; with the amount of Stock in said Banks, held by each Stockholder, and the amount of debt due by each President, Cashier and Director of each of the Banks to the said Bank, at the Time, when it was selected as a depository and at this time; and that the Secretary of the Treasury be directed to report to this House a Statement of all the sums denominated in the Treasury accounts unavailable funds, specifically designating the several banks or individuals indebted to the Treasury therefor; the time when each debt first became due; the time when failure of payment thereof first occurred; the security if any, which the public have for payment thereof at any time, and the prospect of such eventual payment.”— This Resolution now engaged a debate which absorbed the hour and was left unfinished: the names of the lawyers and Solicitors were introduced at the motion of John Ewing of Indiana, accepted by me. James Harper of Philadelphia moved as an Amendment to strike out the call for the debts of Presidents, Cashiers and Directors, to the Banks. Wayne and M’Kinley opposed my Resolution in whole and in its parts— Speight of North-Carolina, and Mann of New-York supported it— Also R. H.
