Wilde of Georgia— Harper finally withdrew his proposed amendment— The hour expired— The Orders of the day were called— Private business. Polk moved to suspend the Rules, to take up the general Appropriation-Bill. The yeas and nays 107 to 82. not two-thirds— Private business resumed— Bill for relief of Edmund Brook, for bringing slaves into the District, ordered to be engrossed for a third reaching next Monday— Three other Bills the same— Bill for the relief of David Kilbourn—a grant of Land as indemnity for Lands of his in Canada, confiscated because he served the U.S. as a spy during the late War, he being a native yankee but a British subject— Long debate. Moses, Joshua, Caleb, quoted by Thompson of Ohio in favour of Kilbourn, and the harlot Rahab, by Chilton against him— Sharp contest between Thompson and Chilton, about moral and religious principle— The Bill was finally rejected by yeas and nays 72 to 86. I voted against it. The House adjourned about 4.— In the Evening I had visits from 3 members of the Committee from the Memorialists of Albany on the Bank and Deposits.
30. VI. Sunday. Easter

Heard this morning at the Presbyterian Church Mr Skinner, from Ephesians 3:4. “For this cause, I bow my knees unto the father of our Lord Jesus Christ.” Took Louisa with me to Church— After dinner I attended at St. John’s, where the Evening service for Easter day was read by an Irishman, I believe named M’Calla, who preached from 2. Peter 2.20. “For if after they have escaped the pollutions of the world through the knowledge of the Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, they are again entangled therein, and overcome, the latter end is worse with them than the beginning.”— In this discourse there was no reference
was made to the festival of the day, which would seem of all other days in the year to be most highly deserving of celebration with religious fervor by Christians— In Roman Catholic Countries and in the Greek Church, it is solemnized with the most animated devotion, and as the day of the Resurrection of the Saviour is more emphatically the Christian’s day, than that of his birth, which is not very precisely ascertained, and if it were, could only be commemorated, as the day of promise, while that of Easter is the day consummated life and immortality.— The Resurrection of Christ, was the accomplishment of the purposes for which he came into the world— Its extraordinary and mysterious connection of coincidence with the Jewish-Passover, gives it great additional interest, and the occasion it has given for ascertaining to the minutest second of time the extent of the annual revolution of the Earth round the Sun, has made it important to the scientific history of Astronomy. For these reasons I have regretted that in the general abolition of religious holidays, by the Protestant Churches of the purest doctrine, they had not made an exception for this day; with which I would also have included Christmas day— In this Country the Catholics, and especially the Episcopalians, keep Christmas with much more earnestness than Easter; the cause of which may be that Christmas is a day for feasting, and Easter is not— The minced-pies and Plum-pudding of the Christmas dinner form for the great multitude of worshippers the keenest incentive to their piety, and the most rapturous of their extasies.

31. V.30. Monday. At the House— Petition day. Plummer of Mississippi, made a Speech against the Natchez Memorials, the Bank of the United States, and his Colleague Harry Cage who answered him— After this warm skirmish the Speaker began with the call of Petitions from Maine’s Edward Kavanagh, presented a deposit memorial from Bath— Evans of Maine one from Somersworth, New-Hampshire, Baylies, one from Bristol County, and Choate one from Lynn, Massachusetts, and Briggs one from the town of Adams, Berkshire County— Baylies in presenting his Memorial made a short commentary upon it. Gayton P. Osgood, presented the Anti-Bank Resolutions adopted at the Faneuil Hall Meeting in Boston, with a few modest remarks— Next came Rhode-Island— Tristam Burges presented a memorial and a Letter from Patterson, New-Jersey, with a Speech— Then a Memorial from the Towns of Cumberland and Smithfield, and from the village of Woonsocket, Rhode-Island, upon which Dutee J. Pearce presents Letters from Olney Ballou and another from William Whipple, a third from Nathan White and a fourth from Richmond Bullock, all tending to cast doubts upon the fairness of the Memorials presented by Burges.— This rouses a furious altercation between Burges and Pearce; in which the Retort Courteous, the quip modest, the Countercheck Quarrelsom, and the lie with Circumstance were banded between them till 4. O’Clock, when the House adjourned— Millard Fillmore moved a reconsideration of the vote of Saturday last rejecting the Bill for the relief of David Kilbourn— The discussion of this motion lies over to another day— I answered two Letters received from Solomon Lincoln with one— I am suffering with a hoarse Catarrh.

Day— I rise at this time usually between five and six, and having transferred to loose sheets my minutes of Diary, which I write from day to day during the Session of the House, I occupy the morning in committing my thoughts to paper, on the Bank and Deposit Questions upon which I purpose to address the House— Rest of the day at the House— Evening sometimes at Cards.
